ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In depth knowledge about Aristotelian philosophy and some contemporary responses

Professor Hagglund essentially does a pitch for his own philosophical project throughout the course- why all living things are necessarily mortal and the rest of his ontology of life. So if you are looking for a history of philosophy or literature on the soul thats not what you are going to get. However, what you get is so much more fun, because Hagglund is so passionate about defending his lifes philosophical project.
Learned about hylomorphism, Aristotelian metaphysics, and other issues concerning the soul.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The courses strength, which is a major one, is Prof Hgglunds intense care and passion for the subject.

Two weaknesses: 1) prof Hagglund could assign some more texts that disagree with his project and 2) Professor Hagglund tends to repeat himself a bit too much because he is super thorough, but at some point you have to let old stuff go so that we can get through the courses material before the end of the term.
I thought this class was very interesting and I enjoyed the material a lot. I wish we had engaged with the readings and philosophers more in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes but definitely only if you're interested in Aristotle, the course mostly revolves around his works and different interpretations and responses to his work.
Yes! You get to talk about the most important questions about what it means to be alive and where meaning comes from and if we are mortal with a very passionate and knowledgeable professor.

Yes, I would! The course will teach you about Aristotelian metaphysics, the soul, and at some points, virtue theory. It is especially good if you're interested in seeing how Martin Hagglund thinks through different issues.
Yes, you should take the opportunity to learn from Professor Hagglund. His work is very different from the rest of the philosophy department and worth learning about.

extras.title: GMAN 288 01/HUMS 480 01/LITR 482 01/PHIL 469 01 - The Mortality of the Soul
